items.title: Clearer documentation on how to run the public oauth script
items.body:
On the Xero website it uses an outdated version of the python wrapper. There is now a XERO_RSA_CERT_KEY_PATH environment variable required to be passed in. However, there is no documentation I am aware of that explains what this should be. It would be helpful to have documentation on how to get this environment variable set up via openssl etc.

The official XERO documentation only says all Public applications must use the HMAC-SHA1 signature method which is not that helpful.

https://developer.xero.com/documentation/auth-and-limits/oauth-issues

has anyone had success in running the public oauth script?

items.body:
I was trying to update the status of a credit note, and it seems that 'ID' was added to the JSON and the Xero API was saying that element is invalid when saving the change. I have since done a hack by removing the 'ID' key from the dictionary before saving.

**Running this:**
credit_note['Status'] = "VOIDED"
xero.creditnotes.save(credit_note)

**Results in this:**
PostDataInvalidException: The element 'ID' was not recognised. Ensure the element name has the correct case and that there are no duplicate elements of the same name.

items.title: PyJWT throws deprecation errors
items.body:
Use of this module throws the following warning:

```
.../lib/python3.5/site-packages/jwt/algorithms.py:178: CryptographyDeprecationWarning: signer and verifier have been deprecated. Please use sign and verify instead.
```

This has been fixed in https://github.com/jpadilla/pyjwt/releases/tag/1.5.3

Recommend setting the minimum version of pyjwt to 1.5.3.

Is there a way to hack this together so delete payment can be achieved via the wrapper?

items.title: Dependency PyJWT is pinned to an insecure version 1.4
items.body:
In [`setup.py`](https://github.com/freakboy3742/pyxero/blob/v0.9.0/setup.py#L33) file dependency `PyJWT` is pinned to version 1.4, which is insecure according to [safety](https://github.com/pyupio/safety) tool.
The description of vulnerability is as follows:
> In PyJWT 1.5.0 and below the `invalid_strings` check in `HMACAlgorithm.prepare_key` does not account for all PEM encoded public keys. Specifically, the PKCS1 PEM encoded format would be allowed because it is prefaced with the string `-----BEGIN RSA PUBLIC KEY-----` which is not accounted for. This enables symmetric/asymmetric key confusion attacks against users using the PKCS1 PEM encoded public keys, which would allow an attacker to craft JWTs from scratch.

Is there really a need to pin ` PyJWT` to version `1.4`?
I can craft a PR to unpin this req.

items.title: Any field ending in "id" is incorrectly treated as a GUID field when used in a filter
items.body:
For instance, the 'AmountPaid' field on invoices is incorrectly treated as an ID field:

```
>>> xero.invoices.filter(AmountPaid=0.0)                                                                           
Traceback (most recent call last):                       
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>                    
  File "xero/basemanager.py", line 204, in wrapper       
    raise XeroBadRequest(response)                       
xero.exceptions.XeroBadRequest: QueryParseException: Operator '==' incompatible with operand types 'Decimal?' and 'Guid'
```

This is because a filter key is considered a GUID type if it ends with "id" as can be seen [here](https://github.com/freakboy3742/pyxero/blob/2ef5e35c0bb3c39977d9eccb79aba8ce41179f1a/xero/basemanager.py#L312).

items.title: How to add LinkedTransactions?
items.body:
`LinkedTransactions` is not available in the list of objects for Xero, I am using this workaround:

```
from xero.manager import Manager
api_obj = Xero(creds, user_agent='my_user_agent')

object_name = 'LinkedTransactions'
setattr(api_obj, object_name.lower(), Manager(object_name, credentials=creds, user_agent='my_user_agent'))
```

After this I am able to use methods like `api_obj.linkedtransactions.filter` and `api_obj.linkedtransactions.all`, but I am unable to create new transactions. When I call the following:

     api_obj.linkedtransactions.put(linked_transactions)

I get a `[None]` response. It does not throw an error and the `LinkedTransaction` objects is not created. Can someone help?

items.title: Marking invoices as deleted
items.body:
To mark an invoice as deleted, the interface in Xero requires a POST (not a DELETE) with the appropriate status (e.g. DELETED or VOIDED). However, the POST request seems to need to be to the single invoice endpoint eg. `/Invoices/INV-234` rather than the general `\Invoices` endpoint, as it returns a 400 error currently when trying to save an invoice with either of these statuses.

See https://developer.xero.com/documentation/api/invoices#post

items.title: Entrust certificate deprecation
items.body:
From Xero:
Important: Starting Jan 1, 2017, we began deprecating support for 2-way SSL for Partner Apps. Please reply to this email and confirm you've received this important information.
 
With this change, you no longer need an Entrust certificate, and you’ll need to update your integration to reference api.xero.com as opposed to api-partner.xero.com.  You can find the most current information in our Developer Center which I have linked to below:
 
Xero Developer Center: Entrust Certificate Deprecation
https://developer.xero.com/documentation/auth-and-limits/entrust-certificate-deprecation


I think we should be safe to change XERO_PARTNER_BASE_URL here,
https://github.com/freakboy3742/pyxero/blob/master/xero/constants.py

And then just drop the parameters here,
https://github.com/freakboy3742/pyxero/blob/master/xero/auth.py#L320

(migration route already documented here: https://developer.xero.com/documentation/auth-and-limits/entrust-certificate-deprecation at the bottom)

Anyone have time to work on this?

items.title: HTTP Error 413.0 - Request Entity Too Large when posting file
items.body:
I am posting file using the below endpoint. > xero_client.filesAPI.files.upload_file(full_path) where full_path is the local path to the file. I got the following error back from Xero. It's really vague btw. ```

HTTP Error 413.0 - Request Entity Too Large

The page was not displayed because the request entity is too large.

Most likely causes:

    \t
  • The Web server is refusing to service the request because the request entity is too large.
    • \t
  • The Web server cannot service the request because it is trying to negotiate a client certificate but the request entity is too large.
    • \t
  • The request URL or the physical mapping to the URL (i.e., the physical file system path to the URL's content) is too long.

Things you can try:

    \t
  • Verify that the request is valid.
    • \t
  • If using client certificates, try:
      \t\t\t
    • Increasing system.webServer/serverRuntime@uploadReadAheadSize
      • \t\t\t
    • Configure your SSL endpoint to negotiate client certificates as part of the initial SSL handshake. (netsh http add sslcert ... clientcertnegotiation=enable)
      • \t\t
    \t

Detailed Error Information:

Module    IIS Web Core
Notification    BeginRequest
Handler    ExtensionlessUrlHandler-Integrated-4.0
Error Code    0x00000000
Requested URL    https://api-partner.network.xero.com:443/files.xro/1.0/Files

This error occurs when the Web server receives a large amount of data from the client. It also occurs if client certificate negotiation occurs while receiving a large request.

View more information »

items.title: Use of bank statement API calls
items.body:
I am using a private application to integrate between Xero and an existing private CRM system to automate receipt of payments / update of account details for payments and to flow invoices across when generated into Xero for accounting purposes.

I had been trying to use the Bank Transactions API to get the details of entries and then bring them across however the number of transactions was a lot lower than expected. From what I can see this API only covers manually entered transactions or other specific bank transactions created and not payment lines that would otherwise come through the bank feeds.

Try as I might I haven't seen an API method in pyxero that provides access to request bank statement lines, before I go trying to work out how to add it in a reliable way can others please check that I haven't missed something obvious (i.e. there is an endpoint and I am being blind)? Or if there is an existing way to obtain this information using other endpoints? Ideally this is getting the lines out of bank feed after they flow in each morning rather than waiting for them to be reconciled / matched to invoices in Xero however that is always an option.

Regards
Alexander

items.title: PyCrypto no longer a hard requirement, please remove from setup.py
items.body:
Hi

PyXero lists PyCrypto in the install_requires. PyCrypto is not directly used by PyXero, but is rather an extra dependency of older versions of oauthlib (https://github.com/idan/oauthlib/blob/0.3.4/setup.py) which is used by requests-oauthlib.

PyXero depends on requests-oauthlib >= 0.3.0 which in turn depends on oauthlib >= 0.3.4. The latest version of requests-oauthlib is 0.5.0 and depends on oauthlib >= 0.6.2. 

The latest version of oauthlib is 1.0.3 and includes significant changes. Significant among the changes in the 1.x.x release of oauthlib is the removal of any dependence on PyCrypto. oauthlib now uses the cryptography library to handle RSA keys and PyCrypto is no longer a requirement.

It would be great if PyCrypto could be removed from the setup.py file for PyXero as this would allow PyXero to be used with PyPy without having to manually check-out the project and patch the setup.py.

It might be best to include a note in the README stating that uses of older versions of oauthlib < 1.0.0 will need to install PyCrypto?

items.title: Attachment request succeeds, but throws exception on parsing the response
items.body:
When using get_attachments() or put_attachment(), the request to Xero works just fine, but then blows up with:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/xero/manager.py", line 184, in wrapper
    return self._parse_api_response(response, self.name)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/xero/manager.py", line 150, in _parse_api_response
    return data[resource_name]
KeyError: u'Invoices'
```

The problem is that parse_api_response is assuming that there will always be a key for the resource name (like 'Invoices') at the top level of the response data.  However, for attachments that is not the case.  From the Xero API docs:

"The response message will contain a summary of the attachment that has been accepted into the API:"

``` xml
<Response>
  <Attachments>
    <Attachment>
      <AttachmentID>e59a2c7f-1306-4078-a0f3-73537afcbba9</AttachmentID>

    </Attachment>
  </Attachments>
</Response>

items.title: Dates in responses in YYYY-MM-DDT00:00:00 format are not parsed correctly
items.body:
I noticed that dates in the above format are not parsed correctly due to a missing module reference in [utils.py](https://github.com/freakboy3742/pyxero/blob/master/xero/utils.py):

``` python
return date(**values)
```

Should be

``` python
return datetime.date(**values)
```

In parse_date(...).

I have the fix and a full set of tests around this and the other expected formats that I can put forward in a PR if you're happy?

items.title: Partner credentials permission denied from Google AppEngine
items.body:
Hello everyone,

Has anyone had issues trying to connect to Xero using Partner Certificates from Google AppEngine?

I allways get "permission denied", it is only from Google AppEngine, I've tried in other environment and it worked fine, but it seems that Google AppEngine take control of the url request at the last point and alters it adding something that Xero doesn't expect so they reject the connection attempt.

I've suggested to use sockets instead of a normal request, but even in that way I'm experiencing the same issue. I wonder if this last case has something to do with the certificate. There are aparently two ways of sending the certificate: one is as a tuple of the paths to the pair of pem files and another it seems to be possible to send a string that, I assume, it must be the content of both pem bundled (but I'm not sure...).
So, my questions are:
One: Has anyone got pyXero and Partnership program to Xero working on Google AppEngine? If so, how? What am I missing?
Two: what should be the content of the cert variable in "PartnerCredentials" class constructor if I chose to send the content of the client certificate instead of the tuple of the pair of pem files paths?

Thank you very much, I'd appreciate any kind of help.

items.title: Exception on "XeroBadRequest" exception class in exceptions.py
Version 0.7.0 pre-release checklist (JSON API)
items.body:
I've just pushed up a change which eliminates the XML parsing for all data retrieval (GET, and the returned response from PUT/PATCH). This wipes out all the walk_dom crap which was causing all sorts of inconsistent responses (dicts instead of lists for singular items) and eliminates a tonne of complexity.

I've also cleaned up the xmlwriting part by explicitly translating between plural and singular verbs -- this will cause problems as I'm sure we haven't included all the mappings we need -- but it's better to have an explicit list rather than try and map between plurals when Xero isn't always consistent.

So, let's get some eyeballs on HEAD and see if it's stable enough to push out as a 0.7.0-alpha release in the next month.
- [x] Have some people use HEAD and confirm everything's working
- [x] Merge all PRs and close all remaining issues
- [x] More unit tests
- [x] Add examples for Public and Partner
- [x] Roll alpha release
- [x] Roll stable release

items.title: Files API
items.body:
I am looking at adding support for the recently released FIles API.

The Files API is a fair bit different to how the Accounting API has worked in the past. For example the Files API is more RESTful. If you were to update and existing folder for example the url would be a POST on  ..../Folders/{FolderID}. The Files API also uses the correct HTTP methods for creating (POST) and updating (PUT) so requests to the Files API are the opposite to what is implemented for the accounting endpoints in the wrapper. It is also JSON by default and much more JSON friendly and the current manager.py handles everything as XML.
All in all a lot of the files stuff would contradict with what is currently in manager.py. 

How would you suggest I go about adding the Files functionality? Would it be best if the manager.py was left for the 'accounting' aspects of the API and I created another class like a FilesManager.py for access to the Files API? Or something else?

items.title: PDF is returned as a Unicode object
items.body:
Hi,

In manager.py, `def get_data(self, func):`

```
        if response.status_code == 200:
            if response.headers['content-type'] == 'application/pdf':
                return response.text
```

the above code returns a Unicode object (because `requests` guesses the response encoding and decodes the response):

```
When you make a request, Requests makes educated guesses about the encoding of
the response based on the HTTP headers. The text encoding guessed by Requests 
is used when you access r.text. 
```

In case of binary files the decoding/re-encoding breaks things - the resulting PDF is broken. Example script:

```
from xero import Xero
from xero.auth import PrivateCredentials

credentials = PrivateCredentials(XERO_CONSUMER_KEY, XERO_PRIVATE_KEY_FILE)
x = Xero(credentials)
invoice = x.invoices.get(INVOICE_ID, headers={'Accept': 'application/pdf'})

with open('invoice.pdf', 'w') as f:
    f.write(invoice.encode('utf-8'))  # can't write without encoding
```

**PROPOSED FIX:** Replacing `return response.text` with `return response.content` solves the issue for me. `requests` docs suggest that `.content` should be used for binary responses.

(Python 2.7)

    from xero.api import Xero

items.title: Always return collections for collection-typed objects.
items.body:
Consider:

```
<Foos>
    <Foo>
        <Bar>baz</Bar>
        <Qux>quux</Qux>
    </Foo>
</Foos>
```

Currently, this returns:

```
{'Foos':{'Foo':{ ... } } }
```

As opposed to:

```
<Foos>
    <Foo>
        <Bar>baz</Bar>
        <Qux>quux</Qux>
    </Foo>
    <Foo>
        <Bar>wibble</Bar>
        <Qux>wobble</Qux>
    </Foo>
</Foos>
```

Which returns:

```
{'Foos': [{'Foo': {...}}, {'Foo': {...}}]}
```

I think that in both cases a list of dicts should be returned, even if said list only contains one dict.

items.title: Reduce verbosity in collections.
items.body:
The Xero API is quite verbose (and generally consistent), where it returns structures that look like:

```
<Foos>
    <Foo>
        <Bar>baz</Bar>
        <Qux>quux</Qux>
    </Foo>
    <Foo>
        <Bar>wibble</Bar>
        <Qux>wobble</Qux>
    </Foo>
</Foos>
```

Currently, this generates a data structure that looks like:

```
{
    'Foos': [
        {'Foo': {'Bar':'baz','Qux':'quux'}},
        {'Foo': {'Bar':'wibble','Qux':'wobble'}},
    ]
}
```

To me, there is no need for the wrapper object 'Foo'. I would propose that it generates an output of:

```
{
    'Foos': [
        {'Bar':'baz','Qux':'quux'},
        {'Bar':'wibble','Qux':'wobble'},
    ]
}
```

Is there a reason I am not thinking of that the previous one is preferable?
